historicalFigures.name: Yoweri Museveni
historicalFigures.background: Yoweri Museveni is the President of Uganda, having been in power since 1986. He led the National Resistance Army (NRA) to overthrow the regimes of Idi Amin and Milton Obote.
keyDecisions: Intervening in regional conflicts (DRC, South Sudan, Somalia).
achievements: Restored stability after decades of chaos.
challenges: Removing term limits and age limits.
historicalFigures.legacy: Museveni is the father of modern Uganda. He is credited with peace but criticized for overstaying his welcome.
quotes: The problem of Africa in general and Uganda in particular is not the people but leaders who want to overstay in power.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He defines the political landscape. His hat and speeches are iconic.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a dictator by the opposition.

historicalFigures.name: Idi Amin
historicalFigures.background: Idi Amin was a military officer who served as the President of Uganda from 1971 to 1979. His regime was characterized by human rights abuses, political repression, and economic collapse.
achievements: Self-proclaimed Conqueror of the British Empire.
historicalFigures.legacy: Amin is the archetype of the African dictator. His rule is known as the reign of terror.
quotes: I am the hero of Africa.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the subject of 'The Last King of Scotland'. A symbol of brutality.
modernInterpretations: Some revisionists argue he was a nationalist who stood up to the West.

historicalFigures.name: Milton Obote
historicalFigures.background: Milton Obote was the leader who led Uganda to independence in 1962. He served as Prime Minister and then President twice, both times ending in military coups.
keyDecisions: Fighting the Bush War against Museveni.
challenges: Coups by Idi Amin and the Okellos.
historicalFigures.legacy: Obote is a tragic figure. He is the father of the nation but also blamed for its instability.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a polarizing figure, loved in the North and hated in Buganda.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a brilliant politician who lost control.
His abolition of kingdoms is still a sore point.

historicalFigures.name: Kabaka Mutesa II
historicalFigures.nativeName: Sir Edward Frederick William David Walugembe Mutebi Luwangula Muteesa II (King Freddie)
historicalFigures.background: Mutesa II was the Kabaka (King) of Buganda and the first President of Uganda. He was exiled by the British and later by Obote.
keyDecisions: Accepting the presidency in a coalition with Obote.
achievements: Major General in the British Army.
historicalFigures.legacy: King Freddie is a martyr for the Buganda Kingdom. His desecration by Obote led to decades of conflict.
quotes: The desecration of my kingdom is unbearable.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is worshipped by the Baganda. His return for burial was a massive event.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a victim of tyranny.

historicalFigures.name: Kabaka Mwanga II
historicalFigures.background: Mwanga II was the Kabaka of Buganda who ordered the execution of the Uganda Martyrs. He resisted British colonization and was exiled to the Seychelles.
keyDecisions: Ordering the execution of Christian converts (1886).
Signing treaties with the British (under duress).
Joining forces with his enemy Kabarega.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mwanga is a complex figure. He is the villain of the Martyrs' story but a hero of resistance.
quotes: I will not give up my land.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Uganda Martyrs Shrine is a major pilgrimage site. He is a symbol of defiance.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a tyrant by the church.
Viewed as a patriot by nationalists.

historicalFigures.name: Omukama Kabarega
historicalFigures.background: Kabarega was the Omukama (King) of Bunyoro. He is famous for his fierce resistance against the British and their Buganda allies using guerrilla warfare.
keyDecisions: Fighting a guerrilla war for 9 years.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kabarega is the hero of Bunyoro. He is a symbol of African resistance.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is honored as a national hero. His tactics are studied.
modernInterpretations: His resistance is a source of pride.

historicalFigures.name: Joshua Cheptegei
historicalFigures.background: Joshua Cheptegei is a long-distance runner and the current world record holder for the 5000m and 10000m. He is Uganda's greatest athlete.
keyDecisions: Recovering from his collapse at the 2017 World Cross Country.
Breaking the long-standing records of Bekele.
achievements: Put Uganda on top of the running world.
historicalFigures.legacy: Cheptegei is the Golden Boy. He proved Uganda can beat the world.
quotes: I want to be the greatest.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He inspires the youth. A national icon.

historicalFigures.name: Stephen Kiprotich
historicalFigures.background: Stephen Kiprotich is a long-distance runner who won the marathon gold medal at the 2012 London Olympics, Uganda's first gold since 1972.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kiprotich broke the curse. His victory united the nation.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He sparked a running boom in Uganda.
modernInterpretations: His victory is a favorite sporting memory.

historicalFigures.name: Philly Lutaaya
historicalFigures.background: Philly Lutaaya was a musician who was the first prominent Ugandan to publicly declare he had HIV/AIDS. He spent his last years campaigning against the stigma.
achievements: Face of the fight against AIDS.
historicalFigures.legacy: Philly Lutaaya is a hero. His Christmas album is the soundtrack of the holidays in Uganda. His bravery changed the course of the epidemic.
quotes: Today it's me, tomorrow someone else.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Philly Lutaaya Day (Oct 17). His music lives on.

historicalFigures.name: Janani Luwum
historicalFigures.background: Janani Luwum was the Archbishop of the Church of Uganda. He was a vocal critic of Idi Amin's brutality and was murdered by the regime in 1977.
keyDecisions: Speaking out against disappearances and killings.
Delivering a protest note to Amin.
achievements: Martyr of the 20th Century (Westminster Abbey statue).
historicalFigures.legacy: Luwum is a saint. Janani Luwum Day is a public holiday. He represents the moral courage of the church.
quotes: I am prepared to die in the army of Jesus.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is one of the ten 20th-century martyrs at Westminster Abbey.
modernInterpretations: His death turned the world against Amin.

historicalFigures.name: Bobi Wine
historicalFigures.background: Bobi Wine is a pop star turned politician. He is the leader of the National Unity Platform (NUP) and the main challenger to President Museveni. He calls himself the 'Ghetto President'.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bobi Wine represents the new generation. He has shaken the establishment.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His red beret is a symbol of resistance. 'Bobi Wine: The People's President' documentary.

historicalFigures.name: Benedicto Kiwanuka
historicalFigures.background: Benedicto Kiwanuka was the first Prime Minister of Uganda (pre-independence) and the first black Chief Justice. He was murdered by Idi Amin for refusing to compromise the judiciary.
keyDecisions: Ruling against the government in sensitive cases.
achievements: Martyr for the rule of law.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kiwanuka is the symbol of justice. The High Court building is named after him.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a hero to the legal profession and the Catholic Church.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a man of principle.
His murder marked the collapse of the rule of law.

historicalFigures.name: John Akii-Bua
historicalFigures.background: John Akii-Bua was a hurdler who won Uganda's first Olympic gold medal at the 1972 Munich Olympics in the 400m hurdles, setting a world record.
keyDecisions: Switching from high jump to hurdles.
Winning gold in world record time.
challenges: Living under Amin (who killed his brothers).
historicalFigures.legacy: Akii-Bua is the pioneer. His 1972 victory is one of the greatest moments in Olympic history.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: A stadium is named after him (in theory).
modernInterpretations: His tragic post-career life is a warning.

historicalFigures.name: Yusuf Lule
historicalFigures.background: Yusuf Lule was an academic who served as the President of Uganda for 68 days after the fall of Idi Amin. He was the first principal of Makerere University.
keyDecisions: Trying to assert authority over the military (leading to his removal).
historicalFigures.legacy: Lule is the scholar-president. His short rule represents the chaotic transition period.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is remembered as a decent man in a dirty game.

historicalFigures.name: Emmanuel Wamala
historicalFigures.background: Emmanuel Wamala is a Cardinal of the Catholic Church and the Archbishop Emeritus of Kampala. He has been a moral voice in Uganda for decades.
historicalFigures.legacy: Cardinal Wamala is a pillar of the nation. He is respected by all political sides.
quotes: Peace is a gift from God.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a father figure to the nation.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a holy and wise man.

historicalFigures.name: Okot p'Bitek
historicalFigures.background: Okot p'Bitek was a poet and anthropologist. He is best known for his poem 'Song of Lawino', a defense of African culture against Westernization.
keyDecisions: Playing football for the national team.
historicalFigures.legacy: Okot is the voice of cultural pride. 'Song of Lawino' is the most famous African poem.
quotes: Let no one uproot the pumpkin in the old homestead.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He influenced a generation of writers.
modernInterpretations: His work is a staple in schools.

historicalFigures.name: Dorcus Inzikuru
historicalFigures.background: Dorcus Inzikuru is a track and field athlete who won the first world title for Uganda in the 3000m steeplechase in 2005. She is known as the 'Arua Gazelle'.
keyDecisions: Running the steeplechase (a new event for women).
historicalFigures.legacy: Inzikuru put women's running on the map in Uganda. She is a legend in the West Nile region.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She inspired many girls to take up sports.

historicalFigures.name: Godfrey Binaisa
historicalFigures.background: Godfrey Binaisa was the President of Uganda from 1979 to 1980. He was a lawyer who famously drafted the 1967 'Pigeonhole Constitution' before falling out with Obote.
keyDecisions: Serving as President under the UNLF.
Trying to transfer powerful military officers (leading to his coup).
Living in exile in the US.
historicalFigures.legacy: Binaisa is a colorful figure. He is remembered for his humor and his short, chaotic presidency.
quotes: Entebbe is sweet (referring to the State House).
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of the post-Amin confusion.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as an intellectual but weak leader.
His 'Entebbe is sweet' quote is legendary.
